column3: MAID Oh, Lord help me, Frank.
column4: SOLDIER Well, what’s the matter with me?
column5: MAID You’re a bad man, Frank.
column8: MAID Why do you leave me alone?
column9: SOLDIER Can’t you let me light my cigar!
column11: SOLDIER It’ll be light again to-morrow morning.
column12: MAID Tell me, at least, you love me.
column13: SOLDIER Well, you must have felt that, Miss Marie!
column14: MAID Where are we going now?
column16: MAID Please, don’t walk so fast.
column18: I don’t like to walk around in the dark.
column19: MAID Tell me, Frank … do you love me?
column20: SOLDIER But I just told you that I loved you!
column21: MAID Won’t you give me a little kiss?
column22: SOLDIER (_Condescendingly_) There… Listen—There’s the music again.
column23: MAID Would you really like to go back, and dance again?
column25: MAID But, Frank, see, I have to get home.
column26: Madame will scold me anyway,—she’s cranky … she’d like it best if I never went out.
column27: SOLDIER Well, you can go home.
column28: MAID But, I thought, Frank, you’d take me home.
column31: MAID Please, it’s so sad to go home alone.
column35: Then we go the same way … but it’s still too early for me … me for the dance… I’ve got late leave to-day… I don’t need to be back at the barracks before twelve o’clock.
column37: MAID Oh, I see, now it’s that cross-eyed blonde’s turn.
column38: SOLDIER Humph!—Her face isn’t so bad.
column39: MAID Oh Lord, how wicked men are.
column40: I’m sure you do the same to every one.
column41: SOLDIER That’d be too much!— MAID Please, Frank, no more to-day—stay with me to-day, you see— SOLDIER Oh, very well, all right.
column42: But I suppose I may dance.
column43: MAID I’m not going to dance with any one else to-night.
column44: SOLDIER There it is already… MAID What?
column47: They’re still playing the same thing … that tatata-tum tatata-tum (_He hums with the band_)… Well, I’ll take you home, if you want to wait for me … if not … good-by— MAID Yes, I’ll wait.
column48: (_They enter the dancehall_) SOLDIER Say, Miss Marie, get yourself a glass of beer.
column49: (_Turning to a blonde who is just dancing past him in the arms of another, very formally_) Miss, may I ask for a dance?— THE PARLOR MAID AND THE YOUNG MAN _Sultry summer afternoon.
column50: The parents of the YOUNG MAN are away in the country.
column52: The PARLOR-MAID is in the kitchen writing a letter to the soldier who is now her sweetheart.
column54: She gets up and goes to his room.
column55: The YOUNG MAN is lying on a couch, smoking a cigarette and reading a French novel._ MAID Yes, Sir?
column56: YOUNG MAN Oh, yes, Marie, oh, yes; I rang, yes … I only wanted … yes, of course… Oh, yes, of course, let the blinds down, Marie… It’s cooler with the blinds down … yes… (_The MAID goes to the window and pulls down the blinds_) YOUNG MAN (_Continues reading_) What are you doing, Marie?
column58: But, now, I can’t see to read.
column59: MAID You are always so studious, Sir.
column60: YOUNG MAN (_Ignoring the remark_) There, that’s better.
column61: (_MARIE goes._) YOUNG MAN (_Tries to go on with his reading, lets the book fall, and rings again_) MAID (_Enters_) YOUNG MAN I say, Marie … let’s see, what was it I wanted to say?
column62: … oh, yes… Is there any cognac in the house?
column63: MAID Yes, but it’s locked up.
column64: YOUNG MAN Well, who has the key?
column68: YOUNG MAN Well, then ask Lini for it.
column69: MAID Yes, but it’s Lini’s day out.
column70: YOUNG MAN So… MAID Can I get anything for you from the café, Sir?
column71: YOUNG MAN Thank you, no… It is hot enough as it is.
column73: Listen, Marie, bring me a glass of water.
column74: Wait, Marie,—let it run, till it gets quite cold.
column76: The YOUNG MAN gazes after her.
column77: At the door the MAID looks back at him, and the YOUNG MAN glances into the air.
column78: The MAID turns on the water and lets it run.
column79: Meanwhile, she goes into her room, washes her hands, and arranges her curls before the mirror.
column80: Then she brings the glass of water to the YOUNG MAN.
column82: The YOUNG MAN raises himself upon his elbow.
column83: The MAID gives him the glass of water and their fingers touch._ YOUNG MAN Thank you—Well, what is the matter?—Be careful.
column84: Put the glass back on the tray.
column85: (_He leans back, and stretches himself_) How late is it?
column87: YOUNG MAN Ah, five o’clock.—That’s fine.— MAID (_Goes.
column88: At the door she turns around.
column89: The YOUNG MAN has followed her with his eyes; she notices it, and smiles_) YOUNG MAN (_Remains stretched out awhile; then, suddenly, he gets up.
column90: He walks to the door, back again, and lies down on the couch.
column92: After a few moments, he rings once more._) MAID (_Appears with a smile which she does not try to hide_) YOUNG MAN Listen, Marie, there was something I wanted to ask you.
column93: Didn’t Dr. Schueller call this morning?
column94: MAID No, Sir, nobody called this morning.
column97: Do you know Dr. Schueller by sight?
column99: He’s the big gentleman with the black beard.
column101: Then, perhaps, he called after all?
column105: MAID (_Coming a little nearer_) Yes, Sir.
column106: YOUNG MAN Still nearer … so … ah … I only thought… MAID Do you want anything, Sir?
column107: YOUNG MAN I thought… Well, I thought—only about your blouse … what kind of a blouse is it … can’t you come closer.
column109: MAID (_Comes close to him_) What is the matter with my blouse?
column111: YOUNG MAN (_Takes hold of her blouse, and draws her down to him_) Blue?
column113: (_Simply_) You are very prettily dressed, Marie.
column114: MAID But, Sir… YOUNG MAN Ah… What is the matter?… (_He has opened her blouse.
column115: In a matter of fact tone_) You have a beautiful white skin, Marie.
column116: MAID You are flattering me, Sir.
column117: YOUNG MAN (_Kissing her on the breast_) That can’t hurt you.
column119: YOUNG MAN But you sigh so.
column121: MAID Oh, Mr. Alfred… YOUNG MAN And what charming little slippers you have… MAID … But … Sir … if the doorbell should ring.— YOUNG MAN Who will ring now?
column122: MAID But, Sir … look … it is so light… YOUNG MAN You needn’t feel at all shy with me.
column123: You needn’t feel shy with anybody … any one as pretty as you.
column124: Yes, really, you are, Marie… Do you know your hair actually smells sweet.
column125: MAID Mr. Alfred… YOUNG MAN Don’t make such a fuss, Marie… Anyway, I’ve already seen you otherwise.
column126: When I came home the other night and went to get some water, the door to your room was open … well… MAID (_Covering her face_) Oh, my, I didn’t know that Mr. Alfred could be so wicked.
column127: YOUNG MAN I _saw_ lots then … _that_ … and _that_ … that … and— MAID Oh, Mr. Alfred!
column128: YOUNG MAN Come, come … here … so—that’s it… MAID But if the doorbell should ring now— YOUNG MAN Now forget that … we simply wouldn’t open the door.
column129: *       *       *       *       * (_The bell rings_) YOUNG MAN Confound it… What a noise that fellow makes—Perhaps he rang before, and we didn’t notice it.
column131: I was listening all the while.
column132: YOUNG MAN Well, see what’s the matter.
column134: MAID Mr. Alfred … you are … no … such a bad man.
column135: YOUNG MAN Please go and see… (_Exit MAID_) YOUNG MAN (_Opens the blinds quickly_) MAID (_Returns_) He must have gone away again.
column136: Anyway, no one is there now.
column139: MAID (_Drawing close to him_) YOUNG MAN (_Evading her_) Listen, Marie,—I’m going to the café now.
column141: YOUNG MAN (_Formally_) I am going to the café now… If Dr. Schueller should call— MAID He won’t come any more to-day.
column142: YOUNG MAN (_Severely_) If Dr. Schueller should come, I—I am in the café.
column144: The MAID takes a cigar from the smoking-stand, puts it in her blouse and goes out._) THE YOUNG MAN AND THE YOUNG WIFE _Evening—A drawing-room furnished with cheap elegance in a house in Schwind street.
column145: The YOUNG MAN has just come in; and, still wearing his hat and overcoat, he lights the gas.
column146: Then he opens a door to a side-room and looks in.
column147: The light from the drawing-room shimmers over the inlaid floor as far as the Louis Quinze bed, which stands against the opposite wall.
column148: A reddish light plays from the fire-place in the corner of the bedroom upon the hangings of the bed.
column149: The YOUNG MAN now inspects the bedroom.
column150: He takes an atomizer from the dressing-table, and sprays the bed-pillows with a fine rain of violet perfume.
column151: Then he carries the atomizer through both rooms, constantly pressing upon the bulb, so that soon the odor of violets pervades the place.
column152: He then takes off his hat and coat.
column153: He sits down in a blue velvet armchair, lights a cigarette, and smokes.
column154: After a short pause he rises again, and makes sure that the green shutters are closed.
column155: Suddenly, he goes into the bedroom, and opens a drawer in the dressing-table.
column156: He puts his hand in it, and finds a tortoise-shell hair-pin.
column157: He looks for a place to hide it, and finally puts it into a pocket of his overcoat.
column158: He opens the buffet in the drawing-room; takes a silver tray, with a bottle and two liqueur glasses, and puts them on the table.
column159: He goes back to his overcoat, and takes from it a small white package.
column160: Opening this, he places it beside the cognac.
column161: He goes again to the buffet, and takes two small plates and knives and forks.
column162: He takes a candied chestnut from the package and eats it.
column163: Then he pours himself a glass of cognac, and drinks it quickly.
column164: He then looks at his watch.
column165: He walks up and down the room.
column166: He stops a while before a large mirror, ordering his hair and small mustache with a pocket-comb.
column167: He next goes to the door of the vestibule and listens.
column169: Then he closes the blue portières, which hang before the bedroom.
column172: Then he sits down in the armchair, and rises only when the door has been opened and the YOUNG WIFE enters._ YOUNG WIFE (_Heavily veiled, closes the door behind her, pausing a moment with her left hand over her heart, as though mastering a strong emotion_) YOUNG MAN (_Goes toward her, takes her left hand, and presses a kiss on the white glove with black stitching.
column175: YOUNG MAN Come, Madame… Come, Emma… YOUNG WIFE Let me be for a minute—please … oh, please, please, Alfred!
column176: (_She is still standing at the door_) YOUNG MAN (_Standing before her, holding her hand_) YOUNG WIFE Where am I?
column178: YOUNG WIFE This house is terrible, Alfred.
column180: It is a very proper house.
column181: YOUNG WIFE But I met two gentlemen on the staircase.
column185: YOUNG MAN But, Madame—You surely know your friends!
column186: YOUNG WIFE I couldn’t see their faces.
column187: YOUNG MAN But even had they been your best friends—they couldn’t possibly have recognized you… I, myself … if I didn’t know it was you … this veil— YOUNG WIFE There are two.
column188: YOUNG MAN Won’t you come closer?… And take off your hat, at least?
column189: YOUNG WIFE What are you thinking of, Alfred?
column190: I promised you: Five minutes… Not a moment more … I swear it, no more— YOUNG MAN Well, then, your veil— YOUNG WIFE There are two of them.
column191: YOUNG MAN Very well, both of them—you will at least let me see your face.
column192: YOUNG WIFE Do you really love me, Alfred?
column194: You ask me… YOUNG WIFE It’s so warm here.
column195: YOUNG MAN You’re still wearing your fur-coat—really, you will catch cold.
column196: YOUNG WIFE (_Finally enters the room, and throws herself into the armchair_) I’m tired—dead tired.
column198: (_He takes off her veil, removes her hat-pin, and puts hat, pin, and veil aside_) YOUNG WIFE (_Permits it_) YOUNG MAN (_Stands before her, and shakes his head_) YOUNG WIFE What is the matter?
column199: YOUNG MAN You’ve never been so beautiful.
column201: YOUNG MAN Alone … alone with you—Emma— (_He kneels down beside her chair, takes both her hands, and covers them with kisses_) YOUNG WIFE And now … now let me go again.
column202: I have done what you asked me to do.
column203: YOUNG MAN (_Lets his head sink into her lap_) YOUNG WIFE You promised me to be good.
column205: YOUNG WIFE It is stifling hot in this room.
column206: YOUNG MAN (_Gets up_) You still have your coat on.
column207: YOUNG WIFE Put it with my hat.
column208: YOUNG MAN (_Takes off her coat, and puts it on the sofa_) YOUNG WIFE And now—good-by— YOUNG MAN Emma—!
column210: YOUNG WIFE The five minutes are long past.
column211: YOUNG MAN Not one yet!— YOUNG WIFE Alfred, tell me truly now, how late it is.
column212: YOUNG MAN It is now exactly a quarter past six.
column213: YOUNG WIFE I should have been at my sister’s long ago.
column214: YOUNG MAN You can see your sister any time… YOUNG WIFE Oh, Merciful Heaven, Alfred, why did you tempt me to come?
column215: YOUNG MAN Because … I adore you, Emma!
column216: YOUNG WIFE To how many have you said the same thing?
column217: YOUNG MAN Since I met you, to no one.
column218: YOUNG WIFE What a foolish woman I am!
column219: If anybody had predicted … just a week ago … or even yesterday… YOUNG MAN But you had already promised me the day before yesterday.
column220: YOUNG WIFE You plagued me so.
column221: But I didn’t want to do it.
column222: God is my witness—I didn’t want to do it… Yesterday, I was firmly decided… Do you know I even wrote you a long letter last night?
column223: YOUNG MAN I didn’t receive any.
column224: YOUNG WIFE I tore it up later.
column225: Oh, if only I had sent it to you.
column226: YOUNG MAN It is better as it is.
column227: YOUNG WIFE Oh, no, it’s awful … of me.
column230: YOUNG MAN (_Seizes her, and covers her face with burning kisses_) YOUNG WIFE So … is that the way you keep your word… YOUNG MAN One more kiss—one more.
column232: (_He kisses her, and she returns the kiss; their lips remain joined for a long time_) YOUNG MAN Shall I tell you something, Emma?
column233: It is now for the first time that I know what happiness is.
column234: YOUNG WIFE (_Sinks back into the armchair_) YOUNG MAN (_Sits on the arm of the chair, and puts one arm lightly about her neck_) … or rather, I know now what happiness might be.
column235: YOUNG WIFE (_Sighs deeply_) YOUNG MAN (_Kisses her again_) YOUNG WIFE Alfred—Alfred, what are you doing to me!
column236: YOUNG MAN Wasn’t I right?—It isn’t so awfully uncomfortable here… And we are so safe here.
column237: It’s a thousand times better than those meetings outdoors… YOUNG WIFE Oh, don’t remind me of them.
column238: YOUNG MAN I shall always recall them with a thousand delights.
column239: Every minute you have let me spend with you is a sweet memory.
column240: YOUNG WIFE Do you remember the ball at the Manufacturers’ Club?
column241: YOUNG MAN Do I remember it…?
column242: I sat beside you through the whole supper—quite close to you.
column243: Your husband had champagne… YOUNG WIFE (_Looks at him with a hurt expression_) YOUNG MAN I meant to speak only of the champagne.
column244: Emma, would you like a glass of cognac?
column245: YOUNG WIFE Only a drop, but first give me a glass of water.
column246: YOUNG MAN Surely… But where is—oh, yes, I remember… (_He opens the portières, and goes into the bedroom_) YOUNG WIFE (_Follows him with her eyes_) YOUNG MAN (_Comes back with a water-bottle and two glasses_) YOUNG WIFE Where have you been?
column247: YOUNG MAN In … the adjoining room.
column248: (_Pours her a glass of water_) YOUNG WIFE Now I’m going to ask you something, Alfred—and you must tell me the truth.
column249: YOUNG MAN I swear— YOUNG WIFE Has there ever been any other woman in these rooms?
column250: YOUNG MAN But, Emma—this house was built twenty years ago!— YOUNG WIFE You know what I mean, Alfred … in these rooms, with you!
column251: YOUNG MAN With me—here—Emma!—It’s not kind of you even to imagine such a thing.
column252: YOUNG WIFE Then there was … how shall I… But, no, I’d rather not ask.
column253: It is better that I shouldn’t ask.
column256: YOUNG MAN But what is wrong?
column257: What is the matter with you?
column259: YOUNG WIFE No, no, no, I mustn’t think… Otherwise I would sink through the floor with shame.
column260: YOUNG MAN (_With the water-bottle in his hand, shakes his head sadly_) Emma, if you only knew how you hurt me.
column261: YOUNG WIFE (_Pours a glass of cognac_) YOUNG MAN I want to tell you something, Emma.
column262: If you’re ashamed of being here—if you don’t care for me—if you don’t feel you are all the happiness in the world for me—then you’d better go.— YOUNG WIFE Yes, I shall go.
column263: YOUNG MAN (_Taking hold of her hand_) But if you feel that I cannot live without you, that a kiss upon your hand means more to me than all the caresses of all the women in the whole world… Emma, I’m not like other young men, who are experienced in love-making—perhaps, I am too naïve … I… YOUNG WIFE But suppose you were like other young men?
column264: YOUNG MAN Then you wouldn’t be here to-night—because you are not like other women.
column265: YOUNG WIFE How do you know that?
column266: YOUNG MAN (_Drawing her close beside him on the sofa_) I have thought a lot about it.
column269: YOUNG MAN Life is so dreary, so empty—and then,—so short—so horribly short!
column270: There is only one happiness—to find some one who loves you.— YOUNG WIFE (_Takes a candied pear from the table, and puts it into her mouth_) YOUNG MAN Give me half of it!
column271: (_She offers it to him with her lips_) YOUNG WIFE (_Catches the hands of the Young Man that threaten to stray_) What are you doing, Alfred?… Is that the way you keep your promise?
column272: YOUNG MAN (_Swallows the pear, then, more daringly_) Life is so short.
column273: YOUNG WIFE (_Weakly_) But that’s no reason— YOUNG MAN (_Mechanically_) Oh, yes.
column274: YOUNG WIFE (_Still more weakly_) Alfred, you promised to be good … and then it’s so light… YOUNG MAN Come, come, you only, only… (_He lifts her from the sofa_) YOUNG WIFE What are you doing?
column275: YOUNG MAN It’s not so light in the other room.
column276: YOUNG WIFE Is there another room?
column277: YOUNG MAN (_Drawing her with him_) A beautiful one … and quite dark.
column278: YOUNG WIFE We’d better stay in here.
column279: YOUNG MAN (_Already past the bedroom portières with her, loosening her waist_) YOUNG WIFE You are so… O merciful Heaven, what are you doing with me!—Alfred!
column280: YOUNG MAN I adore you, Emma!
column281: YOUNG WIFE So then wait, wait a little… (_Weakly_) Go… I’ll call you.
column282: YOUNG MAN Let you help me—let us help you (_becoming confused_) … let … me—help—you.
column283: YOUNG WIFE But you’ll tear everything.
column284: YOUNG MAN You have no corset on?
column285: YOUNG WIFE I never wear a corset.
column287: But you can unbutton my shoes.
column288: YOUNG MAN (_Unbuttons her shoes and kisses her feet_) YOUNG WIFE (_Slips into bed_) Oh, how cold it is.
column289: YOUNG MAN It’ll be warm in a minute.
column290: YOUNG WIFE (_Laughing softly_) Do you think so?
column291: YOUNG MAN (_Slightly hurt, to himself_) She ought not to have said that.
column292: (_He undresses in the dark_) YOUNG WIFE (_Tenderly_) Come, come, come!
column293: YOUNG MAN (_Mollified_) In a minute, dear— YOUNG WIFE It smells like violets here.
column294: YOUNG MAN That’s you… Yes (_To her_) you, yourself.
column296: YOUNG MAN Emma…        *       *       *       *       * YOUNG MAN Apparently I love you too much … yes… I am as if out of my senses.
column297: YOUNG WIFE … … YOUNG MAN I have been beside myself all these days.
column301: It’s perfectly natural, if one… YOUNG WIFE No … don’t… You are nervous.
column303: YOUNG MAN Do you know Stendhal?
column305: YOUNG MAN The “Psychologie de l’amour.” YOUNG WIFE No.
column307: YOUNG MAN There’s a story in that book which is very much to the point.
column308: YOUNG WIFE What kind of a story?
column309: YOUNG MAN There is a gathering of cavalry officers— YOUNG WIFE Yes.
column310: YOUNG MAN And they are telling each other about their love affairs.
column311: And each one of them tells that with the woman he loved best—most passionately, you know … that with him, that then—well, in short, that the same thing happened just as it happened to me now.
column313: YOUNG MAN That is very characteristic.
column315: YOUNG MAN The story is not yet ended.
column316: One of them maintained … that this thing had never in his life happened to him, but, adds Stendhal—he was known as a great boaster.
column317: YOUNG WIFE And.— YOUNG MAN And, yet, it makes you feel blue—that’s the stupid side of it, even though it’s so unimportant.
column319: Anyway, you know … you promised me to be good.
column323: YOUNG WIFE But no, I’m not laughing.
column324: That story of Stendhal’s is really interesting.
column325: I have always thought that only older people … or people who … you know, people who have lived fast… YOUNG MAN The idea!
column326: That has nothing to do with it.
column327: By the way, I had completely forgotten the prettiest of Stendhal’s stories.
column328: One of the cavalry officers went so far as to say that he stayed for three or even six nights… I don’t remember now—that is he stayed with a woman, whom he wanted for weeks—_desirée_—you understand—and nothing happened all those nights except that they wept for happiness … both… YOUNG WIFE Both?
column331: It seems very comprehensible—especially when two people love each other.
column332: YOUNG WIFE But surely there are many who don’t weep.
column333: YOUNG MAN (_Nervously_) Certainly … however, that is an exceptional case.
column334: YOUNG WIFE Oh—I thought Stendhal said that all cavalry officers weep on such an occasion.
column335: YOUNG MAN Look here, now you are laughing at me.
column338: YOUNG MAN Well, it makes me nervous anyway… Besides I have the feeling that you are thinking about it all the time.
column340: YOUNG WIFE I’m not thinking of it at all.
column341: YOUNG MAN If I were only sure that you love me.
column342: YOUNG WIFE Do you want still further proofs?
column343: YOUNG MAN Didn’t I tell you … you are always laughing at me.
column345: Come, let me hold your sweet little head.
column346: YOUNG MAN Oh, that feels so good.
column347: YOUNG WIFE Do you love me?
column348: YOUNG MAN Oh, I’m so happy.
column349: YOUNG WIFE But you needn’t cry about it.
column350: YOUNG MAN (_Moving away from her, highly irritated_) There!
column352: I begged you not to… YOUNG WIFE To tell you that you shouldn’t cry… YOUNG MAN You said: “You needn’t cry about it.” YOUNG WIFE You are nervous, sweetheart.
column354: YOUNG WIFE But you ought not to be.
column355: It is beautiful even that … that we are together like good comrades… YOUNG MAN Now you are beginning again.
column357: That was one of our first talks.
column358: We wanted to be comrades, nothing more.
column359: Oh, how nice that was … at my sister’s ball in January, during the quadrille… For heaven’s sake, I should have gone long ago… My sister expects me—what shall I tell her… Good-by, Alfred— YOUNG MAN Emma!—You will leave me in this way!
column360: YOUNG WIFE Yes—so!— YOUNG MAN Five minutes more… YOUNG WIFE All right.
column362: But you must promise me … not to move?… Yes?… I want to give you a good-by kiss… Psst … be still … don’t move, I told you, otherwise I’ll get up at once, you, my sweetheart, sweet… YOUNG MAN Emma … my ador… …        *       *       *       *       * YOUNG WIFE My Alfred!
column363: YOUNG MAN Oh, it is heaven to be with you.
column364: YOUNG WIFE But now I’ve really got to go.
column365: YOUNG MAN Oh, let your sister wait.
column366: YOUNG WIFE I must go home.
column367: It is much too late to see my sister.
column369: YOUNG MAN How should I know?
column370: YOUNG WIFE You might look at your watch.
column371: YOUNG MAN My watch is in my waistcoat.
column373: YOUNG MAN (_Gets up with a jump_) Eight o’clock.
column374: YOUNG WIFE (_Jumps up quickly_) For heaven’s sake… Quick, Alfred, give me my stockings.
column376: They must be waiting for me at home … eight o’clock… YOUNG MAN When shall I see you again?
column379: Don’t you love me any more?
column380: YOUNG WIFE Just for that reason.
column384: YOUNG WIFE My button-hook is in my bag.
column385: Please, be quick… YOUNG MAN Here is the button-hook.
column386: YOUNG WIFE Alfred, this may cost us our lives.
column387: YOUNG MAN (_Unpleasantly moved_) In what way?
column388: YOUNG WIFE What shall I say, if he asks me where I’ve been?
column390: YOUNG WIFE Oh, if I only could lie.
column391: YOUNG MAN Well, you’ll have to.
column392: YOUNG WIFE Everything for a man like you.
column393: Oh, come here … let me give you a last kiss.
column394: (_She embraces him_)—And now—leave me by myself, go in the other room.—I can’t dress, if you are around.
column395: YOUNG MAN (_Goes into the drawing-room, where he dresses.
column396: He eats some pastry and drinks a glass of cognac_) YOUNG WIFE (_Calls after a while_) Alfred!
column398: YOUNG WIFE Isn’t it better that we didn’t weep?
column399: YOUNG MAN (_Smiling, not without pride_) How can you talk so frivolously?— YOUNG WIFE Oh, how difficult it will be now—if we should meet by chance in company?
column400: YOUNG MAN By chance?—sometime?… Surely you are coming to Lobheimer’s to-morrow?
column404: May I ask for the cotillion?
column405: YOUNG WIFE Oh, I shall not go.
column406: What do you imagine?—I would… (_She enters the drawing-room fully dressed, and takes a piece of chocolate pastry_) sink through the floor.
column409: YOUNG WIFE No, no… I shall decline … certainly decline— YOUNG MAN Well, the day after to-morrow … here.
column411: YOUNG MAN At six… YOUNG WIFE There are cabs at this corner, aren’t there?
column412: YOUNG MAN Yes, as many as you want.
column413: Well, the day after to-morrow, here at six o’clock.
column415: YOUNG WIFE … We’ll discuss that to-morrow night during the cotillion.
column417: YOUNG WIFE Don’t muss my hair again.
column418: YOUNG MAN Well then, to-morrow night at Lobheimer’s, and the day after to-morrow in my arms.
column419: YOUNG WIFE Good-by… YOUNG MAN (_Suddenly anxious again_) And what will you—tell him to-night?— YOUNG WIFE Don’t ask me … don’t ask me … it’s too terrible.—Why do I love you so?—Good-by—If I meet any one again on the stairway, I shall faint.—Ugh!
column420: YOUNG MAN (_Kisses her hand for the last time_) YOUNG WIFE (_Exit_) YOUNG MAN (_Remains standing.
column421: Then he sits down on the couch.
column422: He smiles reflectively, and says to himself_) Now, at last, I have an affair with a respectable woman.
column423: THE YOUNG WIFE AND THE HUSBAND _A comfortable bedroom.
column424: It is half past ten at night.
column425: The WIFE is lying abed and reading.
column426: The HUSBAND enters the room in a dressing gown._ YOUNG WIFE (_Without looking up_) You have stopped working?
column429: And besides… YOUNG WIFE Well?— HUSBAND I felt so lonely at my desk all at once.
column430: A longing for you came over me.
column432: HUSBAND (_Sitting down on the bed beside her_) Don’t read any more to-night.
column434: YOUNG WIFE (_Closing the book_) What’s the matter with you?
column438: YOUNG WIFE One might almost forget it sometimes.
column441: HUSBAND Because, otherwise, marriage would be something imperfect.
column442: It would … how shall I express it … it would lose its sanctity.
column443: YOUNG WIFE Oh… HUSBAND Believe me—it is so… If we hadn’t sometimes forgotten that we are in love with each other during the five years we have been married—we might not be in love any longer.
column445: HUSBAND The case is simply this.
column446: We have had perhaps ten or twelve love-affairs with each other… Doesn’t it seem that way to you, too?
column447: YOUNG WIFE I haven’t counted them!
column448: HUSBAND If we had enjoyed the first one to the last drop, if I had from the very beginning surrendered without restraint to my passion for you, the same thing would have happened to us that has happened to millions of other lovers.
column449: We would be tired of each other.
column450: YOUNG WIFE Ah … do you mean that?
column451: HUSBAND Believe me—Emma—in the early days of our marriage, I was afraid that this would happen.
column455: Therefore, it is wise every now and then to live only as good friends.
column457: HUSBAND And some can always experience new honeymoons, especially since I am careful never to let such weeks of honeymoon… YOUNG WIFE Run into months.
column459: YOUNG WIFE And now … now it seems we are at the end of another such period of friendship—?
column460: HUSBAND (_Pressing her tenderly to him_) So it might seem.
column461: YOUNG WIFE But if … if I should feel differently?
column463: You are the wisest and most delicious being in the world.
column464: I am very happy to have found you.
column465: YOUNG WIFE You know how to make love very well—every now and then.
column466: HUSBAND (_Who has also gone to bed_) Well, for a man who has looked about in the world a bit—come, lay your head on my shoulder—who has seen something of the world, marriage is really something much more mysterious than it is for you sheltered young girls.
column467: You come to us entirely innocent and … to a certain degree, at least, ignorant of things, and therefore you really understand the essence of love much better than we.
column470: For we get all tangled up by the many experiences that we have to go through before marriage.
column471: You women, of course, hear a lot of things, you know a lot of things, no doubt read too much, but you can’t have any real idea of the things men experience.
column472: We men really become quite disgusted with this thing people call love, for the kind of creatures to which we are restricted really are… YOUNG WIFE Tell me—what kind of creatures are they?
column473: HUSBAND (_Kissing her on the forehead_) You ought to be glad, dear child, that you never have had a glimpse of relations like that.
column474: After all most of the poor things deserve pity—it is not for us to throw stones.
column475: YOUNG WIFE But—this pity—it doesn’t seem quite appropriate to me.
column476: HUSBAND (_With gentle benevolence_) They deserve it.
column477: You young girls of good family, who wait quietly under the care of your parents for the man who desires you in marriage,—you won’t know the misery that drives most of these poor creatures into the arms of sin.
column478: YOUNG WIFE Do all of them really sell themselves?
column479: HUSBAND I would hardly say that.
column480: I don’t mean the material misery alone.
column481: There is also—one might call it—a moral misery, a lack of appreciation for what is permissible, and, especially, for what is noble.
column482: YOUNG WIFE But why are they to be pitied?—They seem to enjoy themselves.
column483: HUSBAND You have strange ideas, my child.
column484: You must not forget that such people are predestined by nature to sink lower and lower.
column486: YOUNG WIFE (_Cuddling to him_) It seems pleasant to fall.
column487: HUSBAND (_Hurt_) How can you say things like that, Emma?
column488: I should think that to good women like you, nothing could be more repulsive than those who are not!
column489: YOUNG WIFE Of course, Karl, of course.
column492: I like it when you talk like this.
column494: HUSBAND What?— YOUNG WIFE Why—about these people.
column496: YOUNG WIFE But, I asked you a long time ago—you know, when we were first married to tell me something of your younger days.
column497: HUSBAND Why does that interest you?
column498: YOUNG WIFE Aren’t you my husband?
column499: Isn’t it a sort of injustice that I really know nothing about your past?
column500: HUSBAND You surely don’t think I have such bad taste, as to—No, Emma … it would be like a profanation.
column501: YOUNG WIFE And yet you have … heaven knows how many other women you have held in your arms, just as you are holding me now.
column502: HUSBAND Don’t say “women.” You are _the_ woman.
column503: YOUNG WIFE But you must answer one question … otherwise … otherwise … there won’t be any honeymoon.
column504: HUSBAND That’s a nice way to talk … remember you are a mother … our little girl is sleeping in there… YOUNG WIFE (_Snuggling against him_) But I want a boy, too.
column506: YOUNG WIFE Don’t be silly … of course, I am your wife … but I’d like also to be … to be your sweetheart.
column507: HUSBAND Would you?… YOUNG WIFE Well—now my question.
column509: YOUNG WIFE Was there … a married woman … amongst them?
column512: YOUNG WIFE You know what I mean.
column513: HUSBAND (_Slightly disconcerted_) What makes you think of a thing like that?
column514: YOUNG WIFE I would like to know if … I mean—there are such women… I know that very well.
column515: But did you?… HUSBAND (_Seriously_) Do you know such a woman?
column516: YOUNG WIFE Well, I hardly know.
column517: HUSBAND Is there, perhaps, such a woman among your friends?
column518: YOUNG WIFE How can I be sure that there is—or that there isn’t?
column519: HUSBAND Did any of your friends … women talk about a lot of things—alone among themselves—did any of them ever confess—?
column521: HUSBAND Do you suspect any of your friends—that she… YOUNG WIFE Suspect … oh … suspect.
column523: YOUNG WIFE No, indeed, Karl, most certainly not.
column524: When I think things over—I don’t believe there is any one.
column526: YOUNG WIFE Not among my friends.
column529: HUSBAND That you will never associate with a woman about whom you have the slightest suspicion that she … doesn’t lead a completely blameless life.
column530: YOUNG WIFE And you think it necessary for me to promise that?
column531: HUSBAND I know that you will not seek out the company of such women.
column532: But, it might happen that you … in fact it often happens that such women, whose reputations are not of the best, seek out good women, partly to give them standing, and partly because they feel … how shall I say?… because they feel a certain homesickness for virtue.
column535: I believe what I just said is very true.
column537: For all of these women are at heart very unhappy; you can believe that.
column539: HUSBAND You ask me, Emma?—How can you even ask?—Just imagine what a life these women lead!
column540: Full of lies, perfidy, vulgarity, and danger.
column543: HUSBAND Truly … they pay for their little happiness … their little… YOUNG WIFE Pleasure.
column546: YOUNG WIFE Well,—there must be something in it—!
column548: HUSBAND It is nothing … an intoxication.
column549: YOUNG WIFE (_Pensively_) An intoxication… HUSBAND No, it is not even intoxication.
column550: Like everything—it is dearly paid for, that much is certain.
column551: YOUNG WIFE Well … it has happened to you, hasn’t it?
column552: HUSBAND Yes, Emma.—And it is the thing I most regret.
column557: YOUNG WIFE Was it long ago?
column558: Was it very long before you married me?
column563: YOUNG WIFE Are you in earnest?
column564: HUSBAND Yes … it sounds almost ridiculous, but I have the feeling that all such women die young.
column565: YOUNG WIFE Did you love her very much?
column566: HUSBAND One doesn’t love women who lie.
column567: YOUNG WIFE Then why… HUSBAND An intoxication… YOUNG WIFE Really?
column568: HUSBAND Don’t talk about it any more, please.
column569: All that is passed long ago.
column570: I have only loved one woman—that is you.
column571: You only love where there is purity and truth.
column573: HUSBAND Oh, how secure, how happy one feels in such arms.
column574: Why didn’t I know you as a child?
column575: I am sure I wouldn’t then even have looked at other women.
column577: HUSBAND And how beautiful you are!… beautiful!… Oh, come… (_He puts the light out_)        *       *       *       *       * YOUNG WIFE Do you know what I am thinking of to-night?
column579: YOUNG WIFE Of … of … of Venice.
column580: HUSBAND Our first night… YOUNG WIFE Yes… HUSBAND What then?
column582: YOUNG WIFE You love me as much to-day.
column584: YOUNG WIFE Oh … if you would always… HUSBAND (_In her arms_) If I would what?
column587: If I would always?… YOUNG WIFE Well, yes.
column588: HUSBAND Well, what then, if I would always?… YOUNG WIFE Then I would always know that you love me.
column590: But you must know that anyway.
column591: One cannot always be a lover, sometimes one has to go out into the cold world to struggle and achieve!
column593: There is a time for everything in marriage—that is the beauty of it.
column594: There are not many who can remember their Venice after five years.
column596: HUSBAND And now … good-night, my child.
column598: THE HUSBAND AND THE SWEET YOUNG MISS _A private dining-room in the Riedhof, comfortably furnished with moderately good taste.
column600: The HUSBAND and the SWEET YOUNG MISS are disclosed.
column601: The remains of dinner are on the table, cream-cakes, fruit, cheese.
column602: In the wine-glasses is a Hungarian white wine._ HUSBAND (_Is smoking a Havana cigar, and leaning against the corner of a sofa_) MISS (_Sits beside him in an armchair, eating the cream out of a cake with a spoon, and tasting it with satisfaction_) HUSBAND Is it good?
column607: HUSBAND Your wine is all gone.
column608: (_He fills her glass_) MISS No … stop.
column610: HUSBAND Why are you so shy?
column611: MISS Am I?—Well, it takes time to get acquainted.
column612: HUSBAND Come and sit here with me.
column613: MISS Right away… I’m not ready yet.
column614: HUSBAND (_Rises and stands behind her chair, and puts his arms around her, turning her face toward him_) MISS What’s the matter?
column616: MISS (_Kissing him_) You are … excuse me, you have a lot of nerve.
column617: HUSBAND You’re just finding that out?
column618: MISS Oh, no, I knew that long ago … from the first, in the street.—You must— HUSBAND What?
column619: MISS You must have a nice opinion of me.
column621: MISS Because I went right away with you to a private dining room.
column622: HUSBAND Well, you can hardly say “right away.” MISS But you asked in such a nice way.
column624: MISS And, after all, what is the harm?
column626: MISS Whether we go walking or— HUSBAND Besides, it’s much too cold for walking.
column627: MISS Yes, it was too cold.
column628: HUSBAND But here it’s nice and warm, isn’t it?
column629: (_He sits down again, puts his arms around the girl, and draws her to his side_) MISS (_Weakly_) Don’t.
column630: HUSBAND Tell me… You noticed me before, didn’t you?
column632: Several blocks before you spoke to me.
column634: I mean yesterday and the day before, when I was following you.
column635: MISS A lot of people follow me.
column638: MISS Guess … do you know what happened to me the other day?
column639: My cousin’s husband followed me in the dark, and didn’t recognize me.
column640: HUSBAND Did he speak to you?
column642: Do you imagine every one is as bold as you?
column643: HUSBAND But they sometimes do, don’t they?
column645: HUSBAND Well, and what do you do?
column646: MISS Why nothing—I just don’t answer.
column647: HUSBAND Hm-m … but you answered me.
column649: HUSBAND (_Kisses her violently_) Your lips taste like cream-cakes.
column650: MISS Oh, they are sweet by nature.
column651: HUSBAND I suppose many have told you that?
column655: How many have kissed this mouth before?
column657: You wouldn’t believe me anyhow, if I told you.
column660: HUSBAND All right, I’ll guess—but you mustn’t get angry!
column661: MISS Why should I get angry?
column662: HUSBAND Well, then, I’ll guess … twenty.
column663: MISS (_Slipping away from him_) So—why not make it a hundred?
column664: HUSBAND Oh, I was just guessing.
column668: A girl who lets a man talk to her on the street, and goes right away with him to a private dining-room!
column670: Whether we walk about in the streets or sit in a room… We are in a restaurant.
column671: The waiter may come in at any moment—it doesn’t signify anything at all… MISS That’s just what I thought.
column672: HUSBAND Have you ever been in a private dining-room before?
column673: MISS If I must tell the truth—yes.
column674: HUSBAND I am glad that you are honest with me at least.
column675: MISS But it wasn’t—no it wasn’t the way you imagine.
column676: I was in a private dining-room with a friend and her fiancé, once during the carnival.
column677: HUSBAND It wouldn’t have been anything tragic, if you had ever gone—with your sweetheart— MISS Of course, it wouldn’t have been anything serious.
column681: HUSBAND But you don’t expect to make me believe that I… MISS Make you believe what?… I haven’t any—at least, haven’t had for six months.
column682: HUSBAND I see… But before then?
column684: MISS Why are you so curious?
column685: HUSBAND I am curious because I love you.
column690: (_Presses her tightly to him_) MISS What do you want me to tell?
column691: HUSBAND Don’t keep me in suspense so long.
column692: Who was he, that’s what I want to know.
column695: MISS He looked something like you.
column697: MISS If you hadn’t looked so much like him— HUSBAND Well, what then?
column698: MISS Now, don’t ask, don’t you see that… HUSBAND (_Understanding_) That’s why you let me speak to you.
column700: HUSBAND I really don’t know whether I ought to be pleased or angry.
column701: MISS If I were you, I’d be pleased.
column703: MISS You also remind me of him the way you speak … and the way you look at one… HUSBAND What was he?
column704: MISS And then, the eyes— HUSBAND What was his name?
column705: MISS Please don’t look at me that way; please don’t.
column707: A long, burning kiss_) MISS (_Trembles, and tries to get up_) HUSBAND Why do you want to leave me?
column708: MISS It’s time to go home.
column710: MISS No, I really have to get home.
column711: What do you think mother will say.
column712: HUSBAND You live with your mother?
column713: MISS Of course, I live with my mother.
column716: Do you live alone with her?
column719: Two boys and two more girls.
column720: HUSBAND Don’t sit so far away from me.
column724: She’s working in a flower store.
column729: MISS One of us has to stay home.
column730: HUSBAND Of course,—and what do you tell your mother, when you—come home so late?
column733: Your mother will ask you, won’t she?
column735: It doesn’t matter how careful I am when I come home, she always wakes up.
column736: HUSBAND And what do you tell her?
column737: MISS Oh—that I’ve been to the theater.
column739: MISS Why shouldn’t she believe it?
column740: I often go to the theater.
column741: I saw an opera on Sunday with my friend and her fiancé, and my oldest brother.
column742: HUSBAND Where did you get the tickets?
column743: MISS My brother is a hairdresser.
column744: HUSBAND Oh, yes, a hairdresser … at the theater, I suppose?
column745: MISS Why are you asking so many questions?
column747: What does your other brother do?
column748: MISS He’s still going to school.
column749: He wants to become a teacher.
column751: HUSBAND And you also have a little sister?
column752: MISS Yes, she is a mere child, but you have to keep an eye on her all the time already.
column753: You have no idea how girls are spoiled at school.
column755: The other day I caught her keeping a date.
column758: She was out walking one evening at half-past seven with a boy from the school across the way.
column760: HUSBAND And what did you do?
column761: MISS I gave her a spanking.
column762: HUSBAND Are you as strict as all that?
column763: MISS Well, who would be if I wasn’t?
column764: My older sister is working and mother does nothing but grumble—everything always depends on me.
column765: HUSBAND You are a dear, sweet girl!
column766: (_Kisses her, and grows more tender_) You also remind me of some one.
column768: HUSBAND Of no one in particular … of bygone days … of my youth.
column770: MISS How old are you?… You … why … I don’t even know your name.
column774: HUSBAND Was his name also Karl?
column775: MISS No, but that’s the queer thing … that is … the eyes … (_shaking her head_) the way you look at me… HUSBAND And who was he?—You haven’t told me yet.
column776: MISS Oh, he was a bad man—that’s sure, otherwise he wouldn’t have gone away.
column777: HUSBAND Did you love him very much?
column778: MISS Of course, I loved him.
column779: HUSBAND I know what he was—a lieutenant.
column780: MISS No, he wasn’t in the army.
column782: His father owns a house in … but why do you have to know?
column783: HUSBAND (_Kisses her_) You have gray eyes.
column784: I thought, at first, they were black.
column785: MISS Well aren’t they pretty enough?
column786: HUSBAND (_Kisses her eyes_) MISS Don’t please—I can’t bear it… O, please don’t … let me get up … only for a moment—please.
column788: MISS But, please, Karl… HUSBAND How old are you?—eighteen—isn’t it?
column790: HUSBAND Nineteen … and I— MISS You are thirty… HUSBAND And a little more—Don’t let’s talk about it.
column791: MISS He was thirty-two, when I first met him.
column792: HUSBAND How long ago was that?
column793: MISS I don’t remember… Listen, there must have been something in the wine.
column794: HUSBAND What makes you think so?
column795: MISS I am quite … see—everything is turning round about me.
column796: HUSBAND Then hold tight to me.
column797: So… (_He holds her close to him, and becomes more and more tender.
column798: She hardly resists_) I’ll tell you something, dear, we might go now.
column800: HUSBAND Well, not exactly home… MISS What do you mean?… O, no—no… I won’t go anywhere else.
column801: What do you think I am?
column802: HUSBAND But listen to me, child—the next time we meet, you know, we will arrange it so that … (_He has slipped to the floor with his head in her lap_) This is so comfy, oh, so comfy!
column804: (_She kisses his hair_) Something must have been in that wine—I’m so sleepy … what would happen, if I couldn’t get up again?
column805: But, but—look, but Karl … if some one should come in … please … the waiter.
column806: HUSBAND No … waiter … will ever come in … here…        *       *       *       *       * MISS (_Leaning with closed eyes in the corner of the sofa_) HUSBAND (_Pacing up and down the little room, after having lighted a cigarette_) (_Long silence_) HUSBAND (_Looking for a long time at the girl; speaking to himself_) Who knows what sort of a person she really is—Confound it … so quickly … that wasn’t very cautious of me … hm-m… MISS (_Without opening her eyes_) There must have been something in the wine.
column808: MISS Otherwise… HUSBAND Why do you blame everything on the wine?… MISS Where are you?
column809: Why do you stay so far away?
column811: HUSBAND (_Sits beside her_) MISS Now tell me if you really love me.
column812: HUSBAND But you know that… (_He interrupts himself quickly_) Of course.
column813: MISS Listen… There must have … come, tell me the truth, what was in the wine.
column814: HUSBAND Well, do you think I … I would drug your wine?
column815: MISS Well, see, I can’t understand it.
column816: I’m really not that kind… We’ve known each other only since… Dear, I’m not that kind … honestly, I’m not—if you think that of me— HUSBAND Well—why worry about that?
column817: I don’t think anything bad of you.
column818: I only think that you love me.
column819: MISS Yes… HUSBAND After all, when two young people are alone in a room, and have dinner, and drink wine … there doesn’t need to be anything in the wine.
column820: MISS I merely said it to say something.
column822: MISS (_Almost defiantly_) Because I was ashamed.
column824: There is no reason to be.
column825: Especially, since I made you think of your first sweetheart.
column828: MISS Yes, yes… HUSBAND Now I should like to know who the others were.
column830: HUSBAND That is not true, it can’t be true.
column831: MISS Oh, please, don’t tease me.
column832: HUSBAND Would you like a cigarette?
column834: HUSBAND Do you know how late it is?
column839: She’s used to this, is she?
column840: MISS Do you really want to send me home?
column841: HUSBAND But earlier in the evening you yourself wanted— MISS You are quite changed.
column842: What have I done to you?
column843: HUSBAND But, child, what is the matter with you, what do you imagine?
column844: MISS And it was only your looks, believe me, or you would have had to wait … many men have asked me to go with them to a private dining-room.
column845: HUSBAND Well, would you like … to come here again with me soon … or rather somewhere else?
column847: HUSBAND What do you mean by, “I don’t know”?
column848: MISS Well, why don’t you make a date?
column850: First of all, I must explain that I do not live in Vienna.
column851: I am only here for a few days’ visit now and then.
column852: MISS Oh, you’re not a Viennese?
column853: HUSBAND Yes, I am a Viennese.
column854: But I am living out of town now… MISS Where?
column855: HUSBAND Oh, well, that doesn’t matter.
column856: MISS Oh, don’t be frightened, I won’t come to see you.
column857: HUSBAND If it would give you any pleasure you may come.
column860: HUSBAND Yes, why does that surprise you?
column861: MISS You are married, aren’t you?
column862: HUSBAND (_Greatly surprised_) What makes you think that?
column863: MISS I just got the impression.
column864: HUSBAND And you wouldn’t mind that at all?
column865: MISS Well, I would rather that you were single.—So you are married!— HUSBAND But, tell me first what made you think of that?
column866: MISS If a man says he doesn’t live in Vienna, and he doesn’t always have time— HUSBAND But that’s not so improbable.
column868: HUSBAND And wouldn’t it hurt your conscience to have caused a married man to become unfaithful?
column869: MISS Oh, my, no doubt your wife acts just like you.
column872: MISS I thought you didn’t have a wife.
column873: HUSBAND Whether I have one or not—such remarks are uncalled for.
column874: (_He has risen_) MISS But Karl, Karl, what is the matter?
column876: I really didn’t know that you were married.
column879: HUSBAND (_Comes back to her after a few minutes_) You are strange creatures, you … women.
column880: (_He becomes tender again_) MISS Stop … don’t … it’s too late now.
column881: HUSBAND Well, listen to me a minute.
column883: I would like to see you again, to see you often.
column885: HUSBAND But one thing is necessary … that I can depend upon you.
column886: I can’t look out for you.
column887: MISS Oh, I can look out for myself.
column888: HUSBAND You are … well, I can’t just say inexperienced—but, you are young—and—men in general are pretty unscrupulous.
column890: HUSBAND I don’t mean on the moral side only.—Well, you know what I mean— MISS Tell me, what do you think I am?
column891: HUSBAND Look here—if you want me—me only—we can easily arrange it—even if I do generally live in Graz.
column892: In a place like this where some one may come in at any moment, it isn’t very comfortable.
column893: MISS (_Snuggles up to him_) HUSBAND Next time … we shall go somewhere else, won’t we?
column895: HUSBAND Where we may be entirely alone.
column897: HUSBAND (_Embracing her passionately_) We’ll discuss the rest on the way home.
column898: (_He rises, and opens the door_) Waiter … the bill!
column899: THE SWEET YOUNG MISS AND THE POET _A small room, furnished with taste and comfort.
column901: A large writing-table strewn with books and papers.
column903: The SWEET YOUNG MISS and the POET are disclosed.
column905: The POET closes the door._ POET (_Kisses her_) My darling!
column909: POET Your eyes will have to get used to this semi-darkness.—Those sweet eyes— (_Kisses her eyes_) MISS But there won’t be time enough.
column911: MISS Because I can only stop a moment.
column912: POET But, you can take your hat off, can’t you?
column913: MISS Just for the sake of a minute?
column914: POET (_Takes the pin out of her hat which he removes_) And your coat— MISS The idea!—I have to leave right away.
column915: POET But you must rest a while first.
column916: We have been walking for three hours.
column918: POET Yes, we rode home—but we ran around for a full three hours in the country.
column919: Now come, sit down, child … wherever you like—here at my desk;—no, that’s not comfortable.
column920: Sit down on the sofa.—That’s it.
column921: (_He presses her down_) If you are very tired, you may as well lie down.
column923: (_He stretches her out on the sofa_) There, put your head on the cushion.
column924: MISS (_Laughing_) But I’m not tired at all!
column925: POET You merely imagine you’re not.
column926: So—and if you are sleepy, you can go to sleep.
column928: And what’s more I can play you a lullaby … one of my own… (_He goes to the piano_) MISS One of yours.
column930: MISS But I thought, Robert, you were a professor.
column932: But I told you I was a writer.
column933: But what made you think of that?
column934: MISS Because you said the piece you are playing is your own.
column935: POET Yes … perhaps it is, perhaps it isn’t.
column938: Anyway it doesn’t matter who composed it, if only it is beautiful.
column940: MISS Of course … it must be beautiful … that’s the chief thing!— POET Do you know what I meant by that?
column942: POET By what I just said.
column944: POET (_Gets up, goes to her, and strokes her hair_) You didn’t understand a word.
column945: MISS I’m not as stupid as that.
column946: POET Certainly you are, but that is just the reason why I love you.
column947: It is so beautiful, when girls are stupid.
column948: I mean in the way you are.
column949: MISS Go on, you are talking nonsense.
column951: Isn’t it comfy on this soft, Persian couch cover?
column953: Won’t you play something else on the piano?
column954: POET No, I’d rather stay near you.
column955: (_Caressing her_) MISS But hadn’t you better light the lamp?
column956: POET Oh, no… The dim light is so restful.
column957: We were as if bathed in sunbeams all day.
column958: Now we’ve just climbed out of the bath and slipped on … the twilight like a bathrobe—(_Laughs_) No—that ought to be expressed differently… Don’t you think so?
column960: POET (_Moves slightly away from her_) Absolutely divine, this stupidity!
column961: (_He takes out a notebook, and writes a few words in it_) MISS What are you doing?
column962: (_She turns toward him_) What are you writing?
column963: POET (_Softly_) Sun, bath, twilight, cloak … so… (_He puts the notebook back.
column964: Aloud_) Nothing… Now tell me, sweetheart, wouldn’t you like something to eat or drink?
column965: MISS I’m not thirsty, but I am hungry.
column966: POET Hm … it would suit me better, if you were thirsty.
column967: I have some cognac at home, but I have to send out for food.
column969: POET That is difficult, my servant isn’t here now—but, wait a minute—I will go myself … what would you like?
column970: MISS Oh, really don’t bother; I have to go home anyway.
column971: POET Child, that’s out of the question.
column972: Now I will tell you something; when we leave, we will go together somewhere for supper.
column975: And, then, where could we go?
column976: Somebody we know might see us.
column977: POET Do you know such a lot of people?
column978: MISS Well, it takes only one to make trouble for us.
column980: MISS Well, suppose mother should hear about it… POET We can go somewhere, where no one can see us.
column981: There are plenty of restaurants with private dining-rooms.
column982: MISS (_Singing_) “Let’s dine in a chambre separée!” POET Have you ever been in a private dining-room?
column984: POET Who was the happy man?
column985: MISS Oh, it wasn’t the way you imagine… I went with a friend and her fiancé.
column987: POET And you expect me to believe that?
column989: POET (_Close to her_) Did you blush?
column991: I can’t even distinguish your features.
column992: (_He touches her cheeks with his hands_) But even so I recognize you.
column993: MISS Well, be careful that you don’t take me for some one else.
column994: POET It is strange, I don’t seem to remember how you look.
column997: I can’t imagine any longer how you look—In a certain way I have already forgotten you—Now, if I couldn’t remember even the sound of your voice … what would you do then?—Something near and far away at the same time … it’s uncanny.
column998: MISS What are you talking about?
column1000: Where are your lips?… (_He kisses her_) MISS Wouldn’t it be better to light the lamp?
column1001: POET No… (_Very tenderly_) Tell me, do you love me?
column1002: MISS Very much … oh, so much!
column1003: POET Have you ever loved any one as much as me?
column1004: MISS I told you already that I didn’t.
column1005: POET But… (_He sighs_) MISS He was my fiancé.
column1006: POET I’d rather you wouldn’t think of him now.
column1007: MISS Why … what’s the difference … look… POET We might imagine now that we were in a palace in India.
column1008: MISS I’m sure people there wouldn’t be as wicked as you are.
column1010: Perfectly divine—Ah, if you only know what you are to me… MISS Well?
column1011: POET Don’t always push me away, I’m not going to hurt you— MISS My corset hurts me.
column1016: MISS (_Rises, and takes off her corset in the darkness_) POET (_Sits in the meantime on the sofa_) Tell me, aren’t you at all curious to know my name?
column1018: POET I’d rather not tell you my real name, but the name I go by.
column1020: POET I mean the name I use as a writer.
column1021: MISS Oh, you don’t write under your real name?
column1022: POET (_Close to her_) MISS Oh … stop … don’t.
column1025: (_He kisses her breasts_) MISS You are tearing my chemise.
column1026: POET Away with it … away with it … everything is superfluous.
column1028: POET And now enter into our Indian palace.
column1029: MISS Tell me first—do you really love me?
column1031: (_Kisses her passionately_) I adore you, my sweetheart, my springtime … my… MISS Robert … Robert…        *       *       *       *       * POET It was heaven… My name is… MISS Robert—oh, my Robert!
column1033: MISS Why do you call yourself Biebitz?
column1034: POET My name is not Biebitz—I just use it as a pseudonym … well, don’t you recognize the name?
column1036: POET You don’t know the name Biebitz?
column1039: You are just pretending you don’t know it, aren’t you?
column1040: MISS No really, I never heard it.
column1041: POET Don’t you ever go to the theater?
column1042: MISS Oh, yes—I was at the opera only the other day with—you know, with one of my friends and her uncle, to hear Cavalleria Rusticana.
column1043: POET Hm, you don’t go then to see plays.
column1044: MISS I never get tickets for them.
column1045: POET I’ll send you a ticket soon.
column1049: POET Oh … something funny … you don’t care to see anything sad?
column1051: POET Not even if it is a play of mine.
column1053: Do you write for the theater?
column1054: POET Let me light a candle now.
column1055: I haven’t seen you since you have become my best beloved—Angel!
column1058: Give me a cover at least.
column1060: (_He approaches her with the light, and looks at her a long while_) MISS (_Covering her face with her hands_) Go away, Robert!
column1061: POET You are beautiful, you are Beauty itself.
column1063: You are the simplicity which is holy.
column1065: You are dropping wax on me.
column1066: Look, why aren’t you more careful?
column1067: POET (_Puts the candle away_) You are that for which I have long sought.
column1068: You love me for my own sake.
column1069: You would love me even if I were only a counter-jumper.
column1071: I must confess I was suspicious until this moment.
column1072: Tell me, honestly, you didn’t have any notion that I am Biebitz?
column1073: MISS Oh, pshaw, I don’t even know what you are talking about.
column1074: I never heard of any Biebitz.
column1076: No, forget what I have told you.
column1078: I am Robert and I want to remain Robert to you.
column1080: (_Lightly_) I am not a writer at all.
column1081: I’m a clerk, and in the evening I play the piano in a dancehall.
column1082: MISS But now I’m all mixed up … and the way you look at one.
column1083: What is the matter, yes, what do you mean?
column1084: POET It is very strange—something that has never happened to me, sweetheart; I am on the verge of tears.
column1088: We will be very much in love with each other.
column1089: MISS Is it true about the dancehall?
column1090: POET Yes, but don’t ask any more about it.
column1091: If you love me, don’t ask me anything.
column1092: Tell me, can’t you get away for a few weeks?
column1093: MISS How do you mean get away?
column1094: POET Well, I mean, leave home?
column1098: And without me everything would be topsy-turvy at home in no time.
column1099: POET It would be so wonderful to live with you a few weeks, all alone with you, somewhere far away, in the forest, in the world of nature… Nature.
column1100: And then, some day, “Good-by”—each going, without the other knowing where.
column1101: MISS You are talking already about saying good-by.
column1102: And I thought that you loved me such a lot.
column1103: POET That is just the reason—(_Bends over her, and kisses her upon the forehead._) You sweet darling!
column1106: POET I fancy it’s time for you to dress.
column1107: Wait, I’ll light a few more candles for you.
column1110: (_At the window_) Tell me, child, are you happy?
column1112: POET I mean are you happy the way things are in general?
column1113: MISS Well, they might be better.
column1115: You have told me enough about your conditions at home.
column1116: I know you are not a princess.
column1117: Leaving all that aside, do you feel alive.
column1118: Do you feel life pulsing through you?
column1119: MISS Come, have you a comb?
column1120: POET (_Goes to the dressing-table, hands her a comb, and watches her_) Good Lord, how lovely you look!
column1122: POET Please, stay a while yet.
column1123: I’ll get something for supper, and… MISS But it is awfully late already.
column1124: POET It is not yet nine.
column1125: MISS Dear me, I must hurry.
column1127: POET When shall I see you again?
column1128: MISS When would you like to see me?
column1133: I must take my little sister to her guardian.
column1134: POET Then Sunday … hm … Sunday … on Sunday … now I’ll have to explain something to you.—I’m not Biebitz, but Biebitz is a friend of mine.
column1135: I’ll introduce him to you sometime.
column1136: Biebitz’s play will be given Sunday.
column1137: I’ll send you tickets, and take you home after the performance.
column1138: You will tell me then how you liked the play.
column1140: MISS Here you are talking about this Biebitz again.—I don’t understand what it is all about.
column1141: POET I won’t know you really, until I know what impression the play made on you.
column1144: (_They go out_) THE POET AND THE ACTRESS _A room in an inn in the country.
column1145: It is an evening in spring; moonlight floods the meadows and hills; the windows are open.
column1147: The POET and the ACTRESS enter, and as they cross the threshold, the candle which the POET is carrying in his hand is blown out._ POET Oh… ACTRESS What’s the matter?
column1148: POET The candle.—But we don’t need any.
column1151: ACTRESS (_Sinks suddenly down at the window with her hands folded_) POET What’s the matter with you?
column1152: ACTRESS (_Remains silent_) POET (_Going to her_) What are you doing?
column1153: ACTRESS (_Indignant_) Can’t you see that I am praying?— POET Do you believe in God?
column1154: ACTRESS Of course I do; I am not a fool.
column1156: ACTRESS Come, kneel down beside me.
column1157: It will do you good to pray just once.
column1158: None of the gems will drop out of your crown.
column1159: POET (_Kneels beside her, and puts his arm around her waist_) ACTRESS Libertine!—(_Rises_).
column1160: And do you know to whom I prayed?
column1162: ACTRESS (_With deep sarcasm_) Oh, of course!
column1163: It was to you to whom I prayed.
column1164: POET Then why did you look out of the window?
column1165: ACTRESS Tell me rather where you have lured me.
column1166: POET But, child, it was your idea.
column1167: You wanted to go to the country—and picked out this very place.
column1171: When you consider that we are just two hours from Vienna—complete solitude.
column1174: If you had any real talent, this place might inspire you to write.
column1175: POET Have you been here before?
column1176: ACTRESS Have I been here before?
column1178: I have lived here for years.
column1182: ACTRESS How I adored that man!— POET You’ve told me all about that already.
column1183: ACTRESS I am sorry—I can go away again, if I bore you!
column1184: POET You bore me?… You can’t imagine what you mean to me… You are a whole world in itself… You are divine, you are a genius… You are the simplicity which is holy… Yes, you… But you oughtn’t to talk about Dick now.
column1185: ACTRESS That was merely a slip!
column1186: Well!— POET I am glad that you feel that way.
column1187: ACTRESS Come, give me a kiss!
column1188: POET (_Kisses her_) ACTRESS But now we had better say good night.
column1190: POET What do you mean by that?
column1191: ACTRESS I mean, I am going to lie down and go to sleep.
column1192: POET Yes,—that’s very well, but when it comes to saying “good night” … where do I sleep?
column1193: ACTRESS There are surely a lot of other rooms in this house.
column1194: POET But they don’t appeal to me.
column1195: Don’t you think I had better light a candle now?
column1197: POET (_Lights a candle, which stands upon the dressing-table_) What a charming room … and what pious people they must be.
column1198: Pictures of saints everywhere… It would be interesting to spend some time among people like this … quite another world.
column1199: How little we know of the lives of others!
column1200: ACTRESS Don’t talk nonsense, but just give me the bag from the table.
column1202: ACTRESS (_Takes a small framed picture out of the hand-bag and puts it on the dressing-table_) POET What’s that?
column1204: POET Do you always carry her around with you?
column1209: ACTRESS No, you must go now.
column1210: POET And when may I return?
column1214: POET I shall walk up and down under your window.
column1215: I love to wander about outdoors at night time.
column1216: My finest inspirations come to me that way.
column1217: And especially near you, under the breath of your longing, I might call it … entwined in your art.
column1218: ACTRESS You talk like an idiot… POET (_Hurt_) There are women who might say … like a poet.
column1219: ACTRESS Oh, well, but do go now.
column1220: But don’t start to flirt with the waitress.— POET (_Goes_) ACTRESS (_Undresses.
column1221: She hears the POET going down the wooden stairway, and, then hears his footsteps below her window.
column1222: As soon as she is undressed, she goes to the window and looks down to where he stands waiting.
column1223: She calls to him in a whisper_) Come!
column1224: POET (_Comes quickly upstairs and runs toward her.
column1225: She in the meantime has gone to bed, and extinguished the light.
column1226: He locks the door_) ACTRESS So, now you may sit down beside me, and tell me a story.
column1227: POET (_Sits down on the bed beside her_) Hadn’t I better close the window?
column1228: Isn’t it too cold for you?
column1230: POET Now, what shall I tell you?
column1231: ACTRESS Tell me to whom you are unfaithful at this moment?
column1232: POET I’m sorry, I’m not unfaithful yet.
column1233: ACTRESS Well, if it’s any satisfaction to you, I am unfaithful to some one too.
column1235: ACTRESS And who do you suppose it is?
column1236: POET But, child, how do you expect me to know?
column1239: ACTRESS My dear man, I’m not a chorus-girl.
column1240: POET Well, I am only guessing.
column1242: POET Then it’s your leading-man … Benno— ACTRESS Nonsense!
column1243: He doesn’t care for women at all … didn’t you know that?
column1244: He carries on with his postman!
column1245: POET No, really!— ACTRESS Now come, kiss me.
column1246: POET (_Embraces her_) ACTRESS But what are you doing?
column1247: POET Why do you torment me so?
column1248: ACTRESS Listen, Robert, I have a suggestion to make to you.
column1249: Come lie down in bed with me.
column1252: POET Yes … if I had had my way, I would have been there long ago… Listen… ACTRESS What?
column1253: POET The crickets are chirping outside.
column1254: ACTRESS You are crazy, child, there are no crickets here.
column1255: POET But surely you hear them.
column1258: ACTRESS Now lie quite still… Sh … don’t move… POET Yes, but why?
column1259: ACTRESS You would rather like to have an affair with me?
column1260: POET I should think that’s obvious by now.
column1261: ACTRESS There are many who would like that… POET But it would seem that at the moment the odds are on my side… ACTRESS Then, come, my cricket!
column1262: I shall call you “cricket” from now on.
column1263: POET All right… ACTRESS Now, tell me, whom am I deceiving?
column1264: POET Whom?… Perhaps me… ACTRESS Child, you have softening of the brain.
column1265: POET Or some one … some one whom you have never seen … some one, whom you don’t even know, some one—who is predestined for you and whom you will never find… ACTRESS Please don’t talk such magnificent nonsense.
column1266: POET … Isn’t it strange … you too—and yet one could think.—But no, it would destroy the best in you, if one should … come, come—come.—        *       *       *       *       * ACTRESS That’s better than acting in idiotic plays… Don’t you think so?
column1267: POET Well, it seems to me, that it is a good thing you sometimes have to act in an intelligent one.
column1269: I suppose you are thinking of one of your own plays again.
column1271: ACTRESS (_Seriously_) It is really a splendid play!
column1273: ACTRESS You are a great genius, Robert!
column1274: POET And you might also tell me now why you didn’t turn up the day before yesterday.
column1275: There was absolutely nothing the matter with you.
column1276: ACTRESS Well, I wanted to annoy you.
column1278: What have I done to you?— ACTRESS You were over-bearing.
column1280: ACTRESS Everybody at the theater thinks you are.
column1282: ACTRESS But I told them, he has a perfect right to be over-bearing.
column1283: POET And what did they say?
column1285: I am not on speaking-terms with any of them.
column1287: ACTRESS They would like nothing better than to poison me, every one of them.
column1289: POET Don’t think now of others.
column1290: Let’s be happy that we are here together, and tell me that you love me.
column1291: ACTRESS What further proof can you want?
column1292: POET It’s a thing that can’t be proven anyway.
column1295: POET How many are there that you have tried to convince in this way … did you love all of them?
column1296: ACTRESS No, I have loved only one.
column1299: What can I mean to you, if you are thinking of Dick, now?
column1300: ACTRESS You are a mood of mine.
column1301: POET I am pleased to know it.
column1302: ACTRESS Well, tell me, aren’t you proud?
column1303: POET Why should I be proud?
column1304: ACTRESS It seems to me that you have good reason to be.
column1306: ACTRESS Yes, because of that, my little cricket!—What about the chirping?
column1310: ACTRESS Of course, I hear them.
column1315: POET But this is not croaking, child, this is chirping.
column1316: ACTRESS You are about the most stubborn person I have ever met.
column1318: POET Please don’t call me that.
column1320: ACTRESS Well, what shall I call you?
column1323: POET But won’t you please call me simply by my own name?
column1324: ACTRESS Well, then, Robert, give me a kiss… Ah!
column1325: (_She kisses him_) Now, are you satisfied, froggie?
column1326: POET May I light a cigarette?
column1328: (_He takes his cigarette-case from the dressing-table; takes two cigarettes out; lights both, and gives her one_) By the way, you haven’t said a word about my performance yesterday.
column1335: When you didn’t turn up the day before, I assumed you hadn’t fully recovered yesterday, and so I decided not to go.
column1341: ACTRESS Benno said: Child, you acted divinely.
column1342: POET Hm!… And so ill the day before.
column1345: Because I felt such a longing for you.
column1346: POET A little while ago you said that you stayed away just to annoy me.
column1347: ACTRESS But what do you know about my love for you?
column1349: And I have been delirious for nights.
column1350: In a high fever—hundred and four degrees.
column1351: POET Rather high for a mood.
column1352: ACTRESS You call that a mood?
column1353: I am dying for love of you, and you call it a mood—?
column1355: ACTRESS Dick?… Don’t talk to me about that galley-slave!— THE ACTRESS AND THE COUNT _The bedroom of the ACTRESS, luxuriously furnished.
column1357: The curtains are still down; a candle is burning on the dressing-table.
column1358: The ACTRESS is disclosed in her four-poster bed.
column1359: Many newspapers are strewn about on the cover.
column1360: The COUNT in the uniform of a captain of the Dragoons enters.
column1361: He remains standing at the door._ ACTRESS Ah, Count.
column1362: COUNT Your mother said I might, otherwise I would not— ACTRESS Please, come closer.
column1364: Pardon me—when you come in from the street … I can’t see a thing yet.
column1365: So … here we are (_at her bed_).
column1368: COUNT Your mother said, My daughter isn’t well… Nothing serious, I hope.
column1370: I was on the verge of death.
column1371: COUNT Oh, dear, oh, dear, is it possible?
column1372: ACTRESS It is very good of you to have taken the trouble to call.
column1373: COUNT On the verge of death!
column1374: And only last night you acted divinely.
column1375: ACTRESS It was a great triumph, wasn’t it?
column1376: COUNT Tremendous!… The audience was carried away.
column1377: I won’t say anything about myself.
column1378: ACTRESS Thanks, for the beautiful flowers.
column1380: ACTRESS (_Indicating with her eyes a large flower-basket, which stands on a little table near the window_) There they are.
column1381: COUNT You were literally overwhelmed with flowers and wreaths yesterday.
column1382: ACTRESS They are still in my dressing-room.
column1383: All I brought home was your flowers.
column1384: COUNT (_Kissing her hand_) How sweet of you.
column1385: ACTRESS (_Suddenly seizes his hand, and kisses it_) COUNT But, Mademoiselle.
column1386: ACTRESS Don’t be frightened, Count, it doesn’t put you under any obligations.
column1387: COUNT You are a strange being … a sort of a problem almost— (_Pause_) ACTRESS Miss Birken, I suppose, is much less of a problem.
column1388: COUNT That little lady isn’t a problem at all, although … I really know her only very slightly.
column1392: I’ve always had a yearning for a problem.
column1393: It’s really been a deep personal loss to me, that until yesterday… I _never_ saw you act.
column1396: You see, going to the theater is so complicated.
column1397: I am used to dining late … then when I get there, the best part of the play is over.
column1399: ACTRESS From now on, I suppose, you will dine earlier.
column1400: COUNT I’ve thought of that too.
column1401: Or maybe I won’t dine at all.
column1402: Dining isn’t a special pleasure anyhow.
column1403: ACTRESS Are there any pleasures left to an old man like you?
column1404: COUNT That’s a question I often ask myself.
column1405: But I am not an old man.
column1406: There must be some other reason.
column1409: Bobby, for instance, says, that I am a philosopher.
column1410: You know he means that I do too much thinking.
column1411: ACTRESS Yes … thinking is a misfortune.
column1412: COUNT I have too much time, that’s why I reflect.
column1413: You see, I’ve often thought if they would transfer me to Vienna, things would be better.
column1415: But at the bottom, it’s not really very different from up there.
column1416: ACTRESS What do you mean by “up there”?
column1417: COUNT Well, down there, you know, in Hungary, in the God forsaken country towns, where I’ve been stationed most of the time.
column1418: ACTRESS And what did you do in Hungary?
column1419: COUNT Well, as I am telling you, military service.
column1420: ACTRESS Yes, but why did you stay in Hungary so long?
column1421: COUNT Oh, things happen that way.
column1422: ACTRESS But it must be enough to drive one mad.
column1424: You have a lot more work there, than here.
column1425: You know, drilling recruits, breaking in mounts … and the country really isn’t as bad as they say.
column1426: They are really quite beautiful, the lowlands—and marvelous sunsets.
column1427: Too bad I’m not a painter, I’ve often thought if I were, I would paint them.
column1428: We had a young chap, Splany, in our regiment, who could do it.—But, dear me, what dull stories I am telling you.
column1429: ACTRESS Please go on; they are delightful!
column1430: COUNT Do you know, the nice thing about you is the way one can chat with you, Bobby told me all about it.
column1431: And it’s so seldom one can find any one like that.
column1432: ACTRESS Down there in Hungary, I suppose.
column1433: COUNT But it’s quite the same in Vienna!
column1435: Where there are more of them, the crowd is larger.
column1437: Tell me, do you really like people?
column1440: I hate to look at them.
column1444: COUNT You see, I sort of thought that you hated people.
column1445: It must often be the case with artists.
column1446: If one lives in the higher regions… Well, you are lucky, you know at least why you live!
column1448: I haven’t the slightest notion what I’m living for!
column1449: COUNT But really—to be famous—to be fêted— ACTRESS Does that mean happiness?
column1451: There really is no such thing as happiness.
column1452: All the things that people talk about most, don’t exist … for instance, love.
column1454: ACTRESS I suppose you are right.
column1455: COUNT Enjoyment … intoxication … very good, nobody can deny them … they are something real.
column1456: Now, when I am enjoying myself … very good, I am aware that I am enjoying myself.
column1459: And when it’s over, well then it’s over.
column1461: COUNT But as soon as one does not, how shall I express it, as soon as one does not give oneself up to the moment, I mean, if one thinks of the future or the past … well, everything is over in a moment… Afterwards … there is sadness … before … there is uncertainty … in a word, one only becomes confused.
column1463: ACTRESS (_Nods with wide open eyes_) It seems, you have grasped the essence of things.
column1464: COUNT And, you see, when you have once clearly grasped this, it really doesn’t matter whether you live in Vienna or in the Puszta[3] or in Steinamanger.
column1465: [4] You see, for instance … where may I put my cap?
column1466: Yes, thank you … what were we talking about?
column1469: Well, as I said, there isn’t much difference, whether I spend the evening in the officers’ mess or at the club.
column1472: COUNT If you believe in it, some one will always be there who will love you.
column1473: ACTRESS Like Miss Birken, for example.
column1474: COUNT I really don’t see why you always have to come back to that little lady.
column1475: ACTRESS But she’s your mistress, isn’t she?
column1478: COUNT Except myself, strange to say.
column1479: ACTRESS But you fought a duel on her account!
column1481: I was even killed without my knowing it.
column1482: ACTRESS You are a gentleman, won’t you sit closer to me?
column1485: (_She draws him to her, and passes her hand through his hair_) I knew you would come to-day.
column1487: ACTRESS I knew it last night in the theater.
column1488: COUNT You saw me from the stage, then?
column1490: Didn’t you notice that I acted for you alone?
column1492: ACTRESS I was as on wings, when I saw you sitting in the first row.
column1495: I hadn’t the slightest suspicion that you noticed me!
column1496: ACTRESS Your aristocratic reserve is enough to drive one to despair.
