column1497: COUNT But… ACTRESS “But”!… At least, take your saber off!
column1499: (_Takes it off, and leans it against the bed_) ACTRESS And now give me a kiss.
column1500: COUNT (_Kisses her, she clings to him_) ACTRESS It would have been better if I had never seen you.
column1501: COUNT But this seems better to me.
column1502: ACTRESS Count, you are a poseur!
column1504: ACTRESS Can’t you imagine how happy many a man would be if he were in your place!
column1506: ACTRESS Well, I thought happiness didn’t exist.
column1507: Why do you look at me that way?
column1508: I believe you are afraid of me, Count!
column1509: COUNT I told you, Mademoiselle, you are a problem.
column1510: ACTRESS Oh, don’t bother me with your philosophy … come to me.
column1511: And ask me for anything at all … you can have whatever you want.
column1513: COUNT Well then, may I ask (_kissing her hand_) that I may call again this evening?
column1514: ACTRESS This evening … but I have to act then.
column1516: ACTRESS And you ask for nothing else?
column1517: COUNT I shall ask for everything else after the play.
column1518: ACTRESS (_Hurt_) You can beg a long while then, you abominable poseur.
column1519: COUNT But, see, we’ve been perfectly frank with each other so far … it seems to me it would be so much more beautiful after the play … much cozier than now, when … I have a sort of feeling the door might open any moment… ACTRESS It does not open from the outside.
column1520: COUNT Well, you see, I have an idea one shouldn’t lightly spoil in advance something which may be very beautiful.
column1521: ACTRESS Possibly!… COUNT To tell the truth, love in the morning seems rather horrible to me.
column1522: ACTRESS Well—you are about the worst case of lunacy I have ever met!
column1523: COUNT I am not talking about women in general … because in general it doesn’t make any difference anyway.
column1524: But women like you … no, you may call me a fool a hundred times over.
column1525: But women like you … one doesn’t take them before breakfast.
column1526: And so … you know … so… ACTRESS Oh, but you are a darling!
column1527: COUNT You understand, what I have said, don’t you?
column1528: I sort of imagine it like… ACTRESS How do you imagine it?
column1529: COUNT Like this… I wait for you in a carriage after the play, then we drive somewhere for supper— ACTRESS I am not Miss Birken.
column1530: COUNT I didn’t mean to say you were.
column1531: Only, it seems to me, you have to be in the right sort of mood for everything.
column1532: In my case the mood doesn’t come until supper.
column1533: The most beautiful thing of all is when we drive home together, and then… ACTRESS And then?
column1534: COUNT And then … well, that depends upon circumstances.
column1537: COUNT (_Sitting down on the bed_) Seems to me, that out of the pillows comes a fragrance … mignonette—isn’t it?
column1538: ACTRESS It’s very warm in here, don’t you think so?
column1539: COUNT (_Bends down, and kisses her neck_) ACTRESS Oh, Count, that is contrary to your program.
column1540: COUNT Who said anything about “program.” I never have any program.
column1541: ACTRESS (_Drawing him close to her_) COUNT It really is very warm.
column1543: And so dark, just as if it were evening… (_Draws him toward her_) It is evening … it is night… Close your eyes, if there is too much light for you.
column1544: Come!… Come!… COUNT (_Offers no further resistance_)        *       *       *       *       * ACTRESS And what about atmosphere now, you poseur?
column1545: COUNT You are a little devil.
column1546: ACTRESS What a thing to say!
column1548: ACTRESS You should have been an actor!
column1551: And do you know, what I shall do now?
column1553: ACTRESS I shall tell you that I shall never see you again.
column1557: You would drive a woman mad.
column1558: Here you are standing before me, as though nothing had happened.
column1559: COUNT But… ACTRESS Please remember, Count, I have just given you everything.
column1560: COUNT I shall never forget it!
column1563: ACTRESS Well—you wanted to wait for me after the theater?
column1564: COUNT Oh, yes, let’s say, the day after to-morrow.
column1565: ACTRESS What do you mean by “the day after to-morrow”?
column1567: COUNT There wouldn’t be much sense in that.
column1569: COUNT You don’t quite understand me.
column1570: What I mean has rather to do, how shall I express myself, rather concerns the soul.
column1571: ACTRESS What concern of mine is your soul?
column1572: COUNT Believe me, it has much to do with it.
column1573: It seems all wrong to me, this notion, that you can separate the two.
column1574: ACTRESS Don’t bother me with your philosophy.
column1575: If I want any of that, I can read books.
column1576: COUNT One never learns from books.
column1578: And that’s why you ought to wait for me to-night.
column1579: As to the soul, we will come to some sort of an understanding, you villain!
column1580: COUNT Well, then, if I may, I shall wait in my carriage… ACTRESS You shall wait for me here in my home— COUNT … After the play.
column1582: (_He buckles on his sword_) ACTRESS What are you doing?
column1583: COUNT It seems to me it is time for me to go.
column1584: For a formal call I have stayed a bit too long as it is.
column1585: ACTRESS Well, this evening it shall be a formal call.
column1587: ACTRESS I’ll take care of that.
column1588: And now give me a last kiss, you darling little philosopher.
column1589: Here, you seducer, you … sweet child, you seller of souls, you … panther.
column1590: (_After she has ardently kissed him several times, she thrusts him violently away_) Count, you have done me a great honor.
column1593: ACTRESS Good-by, and love to Steinamanger.
column1594: THE COUNT AND THE GIRL OF THE STREETS _It is morning toward six o’clock.
column1595: A poorly furnished room with one window.
column1596: The dirty yellowish blinds are down.
column1598: On the dresser are several photographs, and beside them a cheap woman’s hat of conspicuously bad taste.
column1599: Behind the mirror are cheap Japanese fans.
column1600: On the table over which is drawn a reddish cover is an oil-lamp.
column1601: It is burning low with a disagreeable odor, and has a shade of yellow paper.
column1602: Beside it is a pitcher with remains of beer, and a half-empty glass.—On the floor beside the bed a woman’s clothes are lying in disorder.
column1603: They look as though they had just been quickly thrown off.
column1604: The GIRL lies sleeping in the bed, breathing quietly.
column1605: The COUNT is lying on the sofa fully dressed with his light overcoat on.
column1606: His hat lies on the floor at the head of the sofa._ COUNT (_Stirs, rubs his eyes, sits up suddenly, remains seated, and looks around_) Where am I?… Oh, yes … I actually went home with the woman, it seems… (_He rises quickly, notices her bed_) Oh, there she is… Queer, what sort of things can happen, even at my age.
column1607: I haven’t the faintest notion, did they carry me up here?
column1608: No… I remember—coming into the room… I was still awake then, or waked up … or … or maybe it’s only the room that reminds of something?… ’Pon my soul, yes, of course … it was yesterday I saw it… (_Looks at his watch_) What!
column1609: yesterday, a couple of hours ago!—But, I knew, that something had to happen… I felt it in my bones … when I began to drink yesterday, I felt that … and what has happened?… Nothing… Or did there…?
column1610: ’Pon my soul … for … for ten years it hasn’t happened to me that I don’t know… Well, let’s be honest at any rate, I was drunk… If I only knew since when… I remember perfectly when Bobby and I went into the all-night café, and … no, no… We left together … and then on the way… Yes, that’s it, Bobby and I rode in my carriage… But, why do I worry my brains about it?
column1612: Let’s see that we get out of here.
column1615: (_Looks at the sleeping GIRL_) Well, she sleeps the sleep of the just.
column1616: I don’t remember anything—but I’ll put the money on the table … and then, good-by… (_He stands in front of her, and looks at her for a considerable time_) If I didn’t know what she is!
column1617: (_Studies her_) I’ve known many who didn’t look as virtuous even in their sleep.
column1618: ’Pon my soul… Bobby would say again, I’m philosophizing, but the truth is, sleep makes all equal, so it seems to me—like its brother, death… Hm, I should like to know, whether… No, I’d remember that… No, no, I dropped like a log on the sofa right away … and nothing happened… It is unbelievable how much alike all women sometimes look… Well, let’s go (_He is about to go_) Oh, of course.
column1619: (_He takes his wallet, and is about to take out a banknote_) GIRL (_Awakening_) Well … who’s there so early in the morning—?
column1625: COUNT (_Bends down to her, considers, and draws back_) I was just going… GIRL Going?
column1627: GIRL You want to go away?
column1628: COUNT (_Half-embarrassed_) Well… GIRL Well, good-by, you’ll come some other time.
column1630: But, won’t you give me your hand?
column1631: GIRL (_Reaches out her hand from under the cover_) COUNT (_Takes her hand, and kisses it mechanically, and becoming aware of it, he smiles_) Just as with a princess.
column1632: Besides, if one only… GIRL Why do you look at me that way?
column1633: COUNT If one only sees the head, as now … anyway, each and every one looks innocent when she first awakes … ’pon my soul, one might imagine almost anything, if the kerosene didn’t smell so… GIRL Yes, the lamps are always a nuisance.
column1634: COUNT How old are you really?
column1635: GIRL Well, what would you guess?
column1640: COUNT And how long have you been… GIRL A year.
column1642: GIRL Better too early, than too late.
column1643: COUNT (_Sits down upon her bed_) Tell me, are you really happy?
column1645: COUNT I mean, are things going well with you?
column1646: GIRL Oh, things always go well with me.
column1647: COUNT Yes… Well, did it never occur to you that you might become something else?
